metadata./Title: Postorgasmic illness syndrome benefiting from omalizumab and antidepressant: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Postorgasmic illness syndrome is characterized by flu, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, loss of appetite, muscle 
weakness, and fatigue after ejaculation, lasting 2–7 days. The multidisciplinary treatment approach, incorporating 
omalizumab and antidepressants, has rarely been documented in literature.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation In this article, we present the case of a 33-year-old single Turkish male with postorgasmic illness 
syndrome, characterized by typical clinical symptoms and a positive autologous semen test. Notably, his serum estro gen and progesterone levels were elevated. The patient’s Beck anxiety score was 42 points, the depression scale score 
was 37, and suicidal thoughts. Fresh autologous semen taken at the hospital was diluted with 0.9% saline, and prick 
and intradermal skin tests were performed.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion The patient’s symptoms improved significantly with the combination of omalizumab and escitalopram. 
This case not only provides a new perspective on the management of postorgasmic illness syndrome but also highlights the potential roles of allergic, psychiatric, and endocrinological mechanisms in the etiology and treatment 
of this complex condition.
Keywords  Postorgasm illness syndrome, Semen, Allergy, Male orgasmic disorders
Background
In 2002, postorgasmic illness syndrome (POIS) was first 
defined by Dr. Marcel Waldinger, who outlined five diag nostic criteria to aid in identifying this condition. These 
criteria provide a structured approach for POIS diagnosis 
and emphasize the consistency and specificity of symp tom onset following ejaculation. The preliminary diag nostic criteria for postorgasmic illness syndrome (POIS) 
are the following [1]:1. At least one of the following symptoms: flu-like sen sation, extreme fatigue or exhaustion, muscle weak ness, feverishness or perspiration, mood disturbances 
or irritability, memory difficulties, concentration 
problems, incoherent speech, nasal congestion or 
watery nose, itchy eyes.
2. All symptoms occur immediately (for example, 
within seconds), soon (for example, within minutes), 
or within a few hours after ejaculation, which can be 
initiated by coitus, masturbation, or occur spontane ously (for example, during sleep).
3. Symptoms occur always or nearly always (that is, in 
more than 90% of ejaculation events).
4. Most of these symptoms last from 2 to 7 days.
5. Symptoms resolve spontaneously.*Correspondence:

Postorgasmic illness syndrome (POIS) is characterized 
by symptoms such as flu, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, loss of 
appetite, muscle weakness, and fatigue after ejaculation 
and usually lasts 2–7 days [2]. Some patients also expe rience neuropsychiatric symptoms such as impaired 
concentration, restlessness, mood disorders, and mem ory problems. Primary and secondary types have been 
defined according to the time of onset of symptoms. 
While symptoms in the primary type begin with the first 
ejaculation, symptoms in the secondary type usually 
begin in adulthood [3]. Although the etiopathogenesis of 
POIS is not known with certainty, it has been suggested 
that it may be associated with psychiatric, allergic, auto immune, endocrinological, and neurobiochemical medi ators [4–6].
The case we are presenting is the first documented 
instance of POIS in Turkey, making it a significant con tribution to the global understanding of this syndrome. 
Additionally, this report is novel in its exploration of a 
multidisciplinary treatment approach that includes the 
use of omalizumab and antidepressants, which has not 
been widely documented in previous literature. This case 
not only provides a new perspective on the management 
of POIS but also highlights the potential roles of allergic, 
psychiatric, and endocrinological mechanisms in the eti ology and treatment of this complex condition.
Case presentation
We present the case of a 33-year-old single Turkish male 
patient with no known illness who did not smoke or 
drink alcohol. The patient was referred to our clinic by 
the urology department owing to complaints of a runny 
nose and itchy eyes. He had no history of sexually trans mitted diseases or surgical operations. The patient had 
rhinitis and conjunctivitis for a long time, and these were 
especially occurring after orgasm. He had complaints of 
stepping on broken glass under his feet, forgetfulness, 
loss of concentration, a tingling sensation throughout his 
body, fatigue, muscle weakness, fever, flu-like condition, 
runny nose, and itchy eyes, which started immediately 
after each ejaculation.
The symptoms were similar during spontaneous sleep, 
masturbation, or vaginal ejaculation. The patient first 
masturbated at the age of 13 years and first noticed the 
relationship between his complaints and orgasm at 
the age of 16 years. The patient stated that he mastur bated every day before these complaints appeared. Until 
5–6  years ago, the patient’s complaints were relieved in 
3 days, but they have continued for about 1 week, during 
the last 3 years. He stated that he had not masturbated at 
all in the last 3 years and that he had taken a 1-week leave 
from work 10 times in the last year owing to these com plaints. While rhinoconjunctivitis complaints generally improved in 3 days, joint pain, forgetfulness, and muscle 
weakness improved in 6–7  days. Postejaculation symp tom severity is shown in Fig. 1.
The patient was diagnosed with POIS as he met the 
symptoms of the POIS criteria.
The secondary sex characteristics and other physi cal examinations were normal, the body mass index was 
22.9 kg/m2. There was no additional disease or medica tion use, and the patient had no drug, food, or venom 
allergies.
The patient, whose Beck anxiety score was 42 points 
and depression scale score was 37, had serious anxiety 
and depression as well as suicidal thoughts. Escitalopram 
was started for depressive complaints. Fresh autologous 
semen taken at the hospital was diluted with 0.9% saline, 
and prick and intradermal skin tests were performed. 
Skin prick testing with autologous semen could not be 
performed in the control group. It was also not possible 
to identify specific IgE and IgG antibodies against semen 
proteins using the patient’s sperm. The skin test

The patient’s routine laboratory tests (blood sugar, liver, 
kidney, and thyroid functions) were normal. Tables  2 
show our patient’s complete blood count, autoantibodies 
total IgE, tryptase, and inhalant allergens.
On the basis of literature and laboratory studies, the 
patient was started on fexofenadine treatment. After the 
initial treatment, ibuprofen, desloratadine/montelukast, 
and silodosin were added in order, and the patient with 
hormonal disorders was referred to the endocrinology 
department. Our patient’s hormone levels are presented 
in Table 3.
The patient, who was not considered for any hormone 
replacement by endocrinology, did not benefit from sil odosin and could not continue the treatment owing to 
gastrointestinal side effects. On the basis of literature 
reviews, we started our patient with omalizumab, which 
is 300 mg per month (Fig.  2). The patient did not respond 
to omalizumab treatment in the first month, and a 
50–60% decrease in symptom severity and duration was 
observed in the evaluation made after the third month of 
treatment.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusion
POIS is a rare disease. Although its etiology is unknown, 
it is generally accepted that it may be related to type 1 
and type 4 allergic reactions and autoimmunity [7, 8]. It is 
thought that there is an immunological reaction between 
semen peptides and T lymphocytes during ejacula tion [9]. In previous studies, it was observed that 88% of 
patients showed a positive skin test with diluted semen 
[8]. A semen skin test was performed on our patient, who

described typical postorgasmic illness syndrome symp toms, and found that the result was positive.
It is stated in literature that a diagnostic criterion for 
POIS is that the symptoms should resolve spontaneously 
within 2–7 days [4]. The patient had complaints of persis tent fatigue and muscle weakness that did not resolve for 
7 days. This might be attributed to the increase in sponta neous orgasms, up to 10 per month, despite a significant 
decrease in the frequency of masturbation.
Since 2002, patients have been given various treat ments such as antidepressants, testosterone replacement 
therapy, intralymphatic immunotherapy, alpha-blockers, 
nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), surgery, 
subcutaneous hCG injections, and antihistamines. How ever, an optimal approach for etiology and treatment has not yet been determined [6]. Bolanos et al. reported nearcomplete symptom improvement in a POIS case treated 
with testosterone [10]. However, since our patient’s tes tosterone levels were normal, we did not pursue hormone 
replacement therapy. After 3 months, the patient’s estro gen levels were normal, while progesterone was at the

treatment. Escitalopram, shown to be effective for post coital dysphoria (depression, anxiety, agitation) [11], was 
prescribed owing to the patient’s depression and suicidal 
thoughts triggered by POIS symptoms. In the case pre sented by Andrew et  al., a 90% improvement in symp toms was described with fexofenadine [7]. The patient’s 
eye and nasal symptoms were significantly reduced with 
fexofenadine 120  mg BID, but no improvement was 
observed in other POIS findings. While allergic symp toms improved with treatment, we added desloratadine/
montelukast and ibuprofen to the treatment regimen for 
the patient who experienced constant fatigue, muscle 
weakness, and pain. However, despite these treatments, 
complaints continued. In the study by Reisman et al., it was reported that 57.1% of patients receiving silodosin 
responded [12]. In parallel with this information, we initi ated silodosin treatment. Since the patient stated that his 
medications were not helpful, it was planned to discon tinue the treatments. However, it was determined that 
the patient did not want to stop taking medication. In 
particular, he stated that the patient wanted to continue 
using escitalopram because the symptoms increased 
when escitalopram was stopped. A study in China (2015) 
noted that autologous semen tests were positive in three 
healthy individuals, but semen-specific IgE could not 
be detected [13]. It was determined that the patient had 
high estrogen and progesterone levels; he was referred to 
endocrinology. Hormone replacement was not required 
in the follow-up.
A limitation of our study was that skin prick test ing could not be performed with autologous semen in 
the control group. Another limitation was that specific 
IgE and IgG semen proteins were not identified using 
the patient’s sperm. Despite reported success rates of 
60–100% with antihistamines, NSAIDs, and alpha-block ers, our patient showed inadequate response [14]. Silodo sin was discontinued in the second month owing to side 
effects (nausea, vomiting). Hyposensitization therapy was 
not an option owing to the need for frequent hospital vis its and insurance issues. Therefore, monoclonal anti-IgE 
antibody was added to the escitalopram regimen. In a 
recent study, we started omalizumab treatment in a POIS 
patient with negative semen IgE owing to the response to

POIS is a rare condition that seriously affects qual ity of life. The diagnosis can be made easily clinically, 
but unfortunately, the exact mechanism and treatment 
of the disease are unknown. In cases where skin tests 
are positive despite a complete response to treatment, 
urological, endocrinological, and psychological evalua tions and a multidisciplinary approach can help to gain 
a more comprehensive understanding of the patient’s 
condition and develop an effective treatment plan.
